title: Area One: Approaches to Play and Learning
subject: Early Learning and Development Standards (2021-)

document.title: VIRGINIA’S EARLY LEARNING & DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS (ELDS): BIRTH-FIVE LEARNING GUIDELINES

4262693E49294E4FB5D6AAE3DCDD05A8.description:
Manages actions,
words, and behavior with
increasing independence
(e.g., matches behavior to
context and expectations)

F772E231BA7640A986BBCD8A855B6984.description:
Follows classroom
rules and routines
more independently
(e.g., morning arrival)

1C35C2201F844892B1188A9FCEFA3A32.description:
Uses classroom
materials with adult
support (e.g., how to
handle appropriately,
how to properly store)

601A92583CA6459C998D879009085A94.description:
Follows classroom
rules and routines with
prompting and reminders
from adults (e.g., uses
visual aids to meet
behavioral expectations

0E31A1833BFD434DB0F6362732461322.description:
Becomes familiar with
basic safety rules (e.g.,
hold an adult’s hand
when crossing the street)

D723D0D4A60543009D8DB0AE7CA15EBC.description:
Participates in simple
routines with adult
support (e.g., hand
washing before eating,
clean up after eating)

C40A08CE22024250A8608FCEDEAF9BD2.description:
Follows simple
instructions from
adult (e.g., puts toy in
a specified location)

047EFFD4B3DF436E915507D01EDB64F0.description:
Follows simple routines
established by adults (e.g.,
eating, napping, playing)

E257F89AC1B9452B8380F0268FD0A4C7.description:
Looks to adult for
guidance before acting
in novel situations (e.g.,
looks at adults’ facial
cues)

B46F95CAA8FE4A48AF80BB0C46C8B16A.description:
Responds to caregivers’
attempts at regulation
(e.g., by rocking, talking
to child)

5E777A86B5784628B660ED1853DEF851.description:
Figures out more than
one solution to a problem
(e.g., using packing
tape with strings to hold
cardboard pieces together
when masking tape
doesn’t work)

3A99B1833A66483A8191A1DE46F99DA4.description:
Sometimes persists in
less preferred activities
with or without adult
support

C0C7EFF171D2428DA277E8DB727C87C3.description:
Responds to adult’s
positive feedback for
effort to continue trying
or practicing a new skill

706F8F26213D43F9A429E394749B0D50.description:
Remembers solutions
discovered before and
uses them (e.g., uses a
spoon to mix flour and
water for playdough
when fingers get sticky
from using hands)

F518E953A76A40639106B9B4E08956C7.description:
Persists in preferred
tasks that may be
challenging, with or
without adult support

968BC6310EC34B42AE2CCBF34896591D.description:
Responds to adult’s
verbal encouragement
to try a new object or
experience or try again
after an unsuccessful
attempt at an activity

AB909F6816BD43C0B45DA8CF90C3AD1D.description:
Alters approach to tasks
when initial approach
does not work (e.g.,
tries different techniques
when assembling a shape
puzzle)

1F75B1B52B2F4CB890836A99CFB90702.description:
Practices a skill or
activity many times,
even with difficulty (e.g.,
building a taller block
tower or balancing on
a log or balance beam)

777B3DF4F3AE41939C948DB213A8E490.description:
Begins to use different
strategies to solve a
problem when one
approach does not work

BF77AB06C8EE43DEBC599D8A0CCF4446.description:
Turns puzzle pieces
different ways to
complete a puzzle

E618500EC380404596679155EA2A6095.description:
Repeats preferred
activities and gestures,
signs, or asks for “more”

165502BF6E5B4C999E286DAE267FE614.description:
Shows increasing
ability to stay engaged
and complete task (e.g.,
putting all shapes in a
shape sorter)

78B15AFBA51645CEAC1243254224E608.description:
Uses trial and error
to solve problems (e.g.,
pressing a lever to make
a particular toy pop up)

4C67CAAD813742BB814D7BC0688C2E49.description:
Persists in looking
to find things that are
hidden

0B1981E8068E453788426FA8C3EAC824.description:
Repeats attempts
to communicate or
repeats actions to get
desired action or object

EC58851D8ADD44C9BE44F56E9183A9E2.description:
Uses more than one
strategy to get what they
want (e.g., vocalizing
as well as reaching
or moving toward)

C2401168D1DF42C6B259F7EAA45D3F92.description:
Repeats attempts to
reach a desired object by
looking at or moving
toward the object

CDAC5765DF57479CB861E21C9629A6C0.description:
Cries persistently until
needs are met

EAEE96E48425437D8DD89E126AAB2156.description:
Uses strategies to help
control own actions
more frequently such as
creating physical distance
or finding an alternative
toy or activity

DADB66A189EA4776962A43F91CBD9D89.description:
Controls impulses with
more independence (e.g.,
walks instead of runs;
asks for a turn with a toy
instead of grabbing; waits
to share out instead of
calling out)

0B17717F88704C908B6525CE1D745E4C.description:
Begins to inhibit
impulsive behaviors
with adult support (e.g.,
inhibits initial response
to call out an answer to
a question during story
time with educator's
reminder)

6FBE7B98F89A4D779C6BF375E2E7CCE3.description:
With adult support,
begins to use words,
signs or gestures to
express distress with
peers (instead of biting or
pushing)

DCC8FE48F8B2488084F63FE70B0AF1D4.description:
Seeks adult help when
distressed with behavior
of or interaction with a
peer

8919B010386847A88E14A37A88808587.description:
Begins to take turns
and waits in line for short
periods of time with adult
support

CDB603D7A969472B997744FF34344CBC.description:
Responds consistently
to adult suggestions to
try out different activities

8411D722DC8A4A6F9F4BFC6F0EF74972.description:
Demonstrates flexibility
and adaptability with less
adult prompting (e.g.,
sharing toys or trying out
new materials)

1FA11B1602404B419B7AC8290F244EAD.description:
Considers ideas from
adults and other children
in finding a solution or
strategy

442FD3D1E61B491CB3269FE46FBAABDF.description:
Adapts to new rules
in game or activity
(e.g., sorting cards by
color and then by shape)

AD07E007A06B47B7B0E0829374C7C193.description:
Shows ability to shift
attention from one task
or activity to another
when necessary

DAD6A02FF1C747D39E36DE21352EE55D.description:
Demonstrates
“cognitive flexibility” by
trying another approach,
with adult support, when
something does not work
the first time (e.g., tries a
different way to climb a
structure when the first
effort does not work or
uses a tool or another
person to get an item out
of reach)

815B4F35128B4FDDB17876FC98B03665.description:
Makes transitions
that are part of a daily
schedule

87FB777D08C34D6DBF70F31A7AF50066.description:
Identifies signals
for changes between
activities

DBEB56DF6854433E8A5BB3DAE888C4DA.description:
Adjusts to changes in
routines when informed
in advance

6261993B78C0495694F831CE4700D86B.description:
Modifies actions
or behavior in social
situations, daily routines,
to problem solve

1F4843B6DC0A44F4A459E7AFB62BCE23.description:
Tries a variety of
approaches to get what is
wanted

7A3AE366AFAE4803A4B1FC6B6858A57C.description:
Allows caregiver to
interrupt an activity to
perform a routine as long
as the caregiver notifies
in advance (e.g., child
playing with toy allows
caregiver to wipe face)

B6AD53B77842486695375142D60AE22E.description:
Participates in a new
activity or tries new ways
to solve a problem with
little protest

B47ECB8BE41E4D3DB6296B5CDB4A5075.description:
Shows ability to
shift focus to attend to
something else

1D84A0AF4D154BCEA96284FFC80DA736.description:
Modifies expressions
and actions based on
others’ responses (e.g.,
begins to smile in
response to caregiver’s
smiling face)

FA34FFFC9C0C4D4BB0AD6316F00FEAE9.description:
Explores objects by
putting in the mouth and
then rattling or shaking

4176978E55E749F993F6EA49DE995C8F.description:
Teaches another child
the steps taken for a
given action (e.g., shows
a peer how to use soap to
wash hands before snack)

FDD8A9E32D4B4BFBBBE4836402F7F469.description:
Remembers actions
that go with stories or
songs

AB63EBCF167647B38E9DCFDCD3B8FCE5.description:
Remembers several
steps in sequence to
complete multi-step
directions (e.g., complete
a puzzle, return it to the
shelf, and join the group
at the rug)

7D7DB89DB83F4E3EB4460AB4AE665392.description:
Remembers and
follows 2-step directions
to complete simple tasks
(e.g., “wash your hands
then help prepare or eat a
snack”)

86C5418B18FB49C79553202696ED954C.description:
Plays simple memory
and matching games

952D5326D1194BA5B64A006294829EAF.description:
Repeats a list of items
needed for self-care or
play

F4D3493BB6A04EA5B0B91455D4069EE3.description:
Remembers where
materials are kept in
familiar environments
(e.g., can retrieve spare
clothes from cubby)

CFE9112A433F4182895844F402B13E79.description:
Practices remembering
by recounting a story
or verbally describing a
picture no longer in view

C2D55F7777C0428EBEEFB1A7958DC0B9.description:
Follows simple 1-step
verbal directions like “put
your spare clothes in your
cubby”

3967FCB7048E4F8D9AB04E0B6979BF5F.description:
Sings some of the
words to a favorite song

520A2F5E87694A14BEAADD1B7803C881.description:
Points to and names
parents, siblings, body
parts, and familiar objects

DD6AA421D37C4770BBE2B48A04E9C0D3.description:
Correctly looks and
reaches toward a toy’s
hiding place when the
place has been changed
from one location to
another

7CBB4D9960314142A8055C204277070D.description:
Shows recognition and
memory of familiar faces
and objects over longer
periods of time since last
seen

B8E41FCFA6D04D33B8BC193FE4927DB5.description:
Develops expectations
of what will happen
based on prior
experiences (e.g.,
caregiver will come
when baby cries)

4C733AEDB0284FA3B5F427827E750D5C.description:
Shows recognition of
familiar faces and voices
by attending to that
person

A89AEE33AA2D48DE981C6C25B865E2F7.description:
Begins to attend to
adult-initiated tasks that
are not based on their
interests (e.g., participates
in a teacher-led small or
large group)

84338D2C2F084CC6B749B36AC922C8FB.description:
Sustains engagement
with a task that interests
them for long periods
of time (e.g., works in
the art center creating
watercolor paintings for
30 minutes)

1F5074965D1046129DCD9D657D58E5CF.description:
Focuses attention
on tasks and activities
like painting or block
building for longer
periods of time with
increasing independence

540849EDD564409F975321CB66CA7D94.description:
Stays with a variety
of tasks that interest
them (e.g., plays in the
dramatic play and block
areas for 10 minutes)

3D73BD2C59584639B3E1BF48D8F93326.description:
With adult prompts
and support, focuses
attention on activities
like listening to stories
read to a group for
short periods of time in
spite of interruptions or
distraction

5F864F1CDD134D1D852A7B059A1B02BE.description:
Sustains interest with
one or two tasks that
engage them (e.g., plays
at the sensory table for
5-10 minutes)

70FCCE84D5B14280B735F4A4711B3EC5.description:
Focuses on self-initiated activities for a
short amount of time
(e.g., works on a puzzle)

C1027A289CBF4E7B860EEDFEEBAD1228.description:
Participates in activities
with people and materials
that require attention like
listening to simple stories
as they are read

C4727F96B6574ED68005B51F6FACF4AA.description:
Kicks a toy repeatedly
and notices the
movement of the toy

9D1E5F7BA5A0414389F0F8E4B8543D77.description:
Notices when
something expected does
not happen

CDCEE88E821B48F8B7662162A6503D87.description:
Demonstrates
increasing ability to
attend to people, objects,
and activities (e.g.,
quiets motor movements
and shows intense
concentration)

925D4BE30E34401EAEDD22295E821503.description:
Limits sensory input
by breaking gaze and
shifting attention

A0FA1FF5FF404A13A230C891714D5AEB.description:
With adult support,
starts to filter distractions
to focus on people or
objects in environment

22F7423E0CAA49E08D701D54EFC62C7E.description:
Shows purpose and
inventiveness in play
(e.g., collects different
shapes of blocks to build
a castle)

A106325505A0473D83DF1819933AEBB0.description:
Utilizes realistic and
open-ended materials
in cooperative play

827642D354AC46809E53500E76BD4D0B.description:
Represents reality
through the arts and with
art materials (e.g., by
creating stories, drawing,
or enacting experiences
in dramatic play)

FD74DE21951C4DA5AA0339F901ED7069.description:
Connects dramatic
play to story (e.g., acts
as a familiar character)

72EFF7A1FC8B4830AD73F66951E5B293.description:
Begins to sequence
actions in dramatic
play (e.g., gathers pots,
spoons, and plastic
vegetables to “make
soup”)

AE2FA683BA7146F2BC355F37C859CAED.description:
Transitions between
reality and imagination
in cooperative play,
dramatic play, or during
guided drama experience

88B81599E0F74A2AA4E7F1278C6120F1.description:
Incorporates props
while talking about
actions (e.g., takes
play dough to the
housekeeping area to fill
muffin tins before putting
them in the play oven)

74419B4EFE68439FB899A9ED90097819.description:
Creates three
dimensional structures
using blocks and found
materials (e.g., stones or
sticks)

337A07C5276441A48146196CE43359EA.description:
Reenacts familiar
events using props (e.g.,
pats a doll on the back,
says, “night, night” and
puts it in the toy bed)

7B688AFAA3A8488CB175DEDCCFC09380.description:
Shows imagination by
using objects to stand-in
for other objects (e.g.,
uses a block to represent
a phone or a car)

4B20CD6144D94D5FB99225D98DB55A71.description:
Plays with stuffed
animals as though they
were real

5B6F37C029784AC4A3470ABBC2CA4BFB.description:
Uses realistic objects
in pretend play (e.g.,
pretends to fit toy
keys into a door lock)

C74637884CD643178E29EBA27B356328.description:
Uses everyday objects
for a variety of purposes

C29924CF943941A095339C629A10B244.description:
Imitates simple
actions (e.g., claps hands
together, covers eyes
with hands)

7421D1321D284AF0872F78CE0E688219.description:
Observes other people’s
use of objects

4EAB8F4F05B8492997F723E753953903.description:
Explores toys and safe
objects with hands and
mouth

C42DB8AC0F52400D9260D06C6D10439E.description:
Seeks new challenges
with familiar materials
and activities
independently (e.g.,
climbs up the slide)

9AD6E269543F4B36A4BAD7EEFFBEAE16.description:
Suggests new ideas
for play activities and
follows through with
self-direction and
independence

30C7C10E534F4D9AAB4BE026F52640DC.description:
Chooses different
ways to explore the
environment based
on prior experiences
with tools or actions

36E08D9CA775432C8DDE203BDE6ABD24.description:
Makes attempts at new
and challenging activities
(e.g., climbs a new,
higher slide)

9DAEE5828C1642FABB392D882D0AC9E1.description:
Purposely tries different
ways of doing things
to see what happens
(e.g., builds ramps with
different blocks to make
their cars go faster and
farther)

75AC11D182ED493282F93D43CE1BDE2A.description:
Tries out different
ways of using new
materials

C3B819F55A97497DA7AFB54BFA67EB3D.description:
Uses toys to make
things happen (e.g.,
pushes a button on a
toy to create a sound)

82217F7BBC10419E9B33AA9FF2797248.description:
Initiates activities of
interest and tries to get
others involved

1EB43F4BDC1B402E8110FFC46921492A.description:
Initiates turn-taking
with familiar adults (e.g.,
gives parent a toy and
parent offers a new toy)

D6BCC1276CCB471BA5D4519CC3B9E5FC.description:
Plays with one object
for a few minutes before
focusing on a different
object

9E98B367DA3F467D88050F10A499F3ED.description:
Seeks out objects that
an adult hides

8110885A84914F8B95B6D81C1BBF2F6B.description:
Moves toward
interesting people,
sounds, objects, and
activities

B7DDEE11154D48C1934B04B265388146.description:
Explores objects using
their senses and by
manipulating them in
a variety of ways (e.g.,
bangs, shakes, throws)

BCA18DB89F1445F09931F2FAEF7973E8.description:
Repeats actions on
objects to get same
reaction from the object
(e.g., kicking items on
mobile, moving arms to
sound rattle or bell noise
on wrist)

3C4E80B2BCC24F7988113E434FE17357.description:
Repeats actions to
get same reaction from
an adult (e.g., smiling,
laughing, verbalizing)

703E1DDB117C44C688085EB95BB147BB.description:
Reaches, stretches, or
works to crawl towards a
desired object or person

D3C59EECEE2C4F008753F1D143E1434B.description:
Explores their own
body by mouthing and
clapping hands and by
kicking and touching feet

D919D922C9BB4DA19C2A5295D09BC469.description:
Shows eagerness to
learn about a variety of
topics

8CE655937D314E60B1B7AE7613E2A96D.description:
Seeks out new
information by asking,
“How does that work?” (Later Preschool 44-60 months)

2E920D08CA304D8391439799BB241C44.description:
Shows curiosity by
saying things like, “I
wonder what will happen
next.” (Later Preschool
44-60 months)

82CE00306B6C429AA1D87E54BF8D0951.description:
Seeks out new
information, asks “Why?” (Early Preschool
34-48 months)

31B79E71CED440A8939567C674246E0B.description:
Shows interest and
awareness in changes
in the environment

39C615D9C4F64BBBA43344F35C2C4171.description:
Asks questions about
materials and how they
are used

2E26D85D7841450F8B1FA1A18C5E0C30.description:
Participates in new
experiences, begins
to ask questions, and
experiments with new
materials

75B377DC9F9943E1B7B5AEF376084C11.description:
Shows interest in
new experiences such as
reaching out to touch
rain, hearing a new song,
or examining new items

6586EA712A9F455BA1E2C3130148D498.description:
Shows excitement
with facial expressions,
vocalizations, or physical
movements.

81AD7D253CA34550A82436B01DCC000A.description:
Shows awareness of
what is going on around
them by turning their
head and looking around.
